newsitem.title: SURINAM: New Surinam chief to seek help from former foes.
newsitem.headline: New Surinam chief to seek help from former foes.

text.p: Surinam's new President Jules Wijdenbosch, who is backed by former military strongman Desi Bouterse, took office on Sunday and vowed to seek cooperation with his former political foes.
"In our policy we will not distinguish between political colour because the crisis does not either," Wijdenbosch said during his acceptance speech.
Wijdenbosch, 55, won a narrow presidential runoff against former President Ronald Venetiaan last week to bring Bouterse's National Democratic Party (NDP) its first ever victory at the polls.
In a long speech short on specifics, Wijdenbosch said his government would launch a 100-day "crisis project" while continuing talks with society leaders to work on a longer-term programme.
Wijdenbosch, who held key posts in Bouterse's military governments of the 1980s, said the crisis project would tackle rising crime, housing shortages, education and infrastructure.
"With true and inspiring leadership the nation will be built," he said.
Wijdenbosch's victory has led to fears at home and abroad that the former Dutch colony will return to the dark years of the 1980s when Surinam became internationally isolated.
Surinam, a multi-racial country of 400,000, endured two military coups, seven years of dictatorship and widespread guerrilla activity in the last two decades.
